titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck, May 11, 1909
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
titleStmt.sponsor: Supported in part by a grant from the Wyoming Cultural Trust Fund, a program of the Department of State Parks and Cultural Resources.

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck

msIdentifier.repository: University of Wyoming, American Heritage Center, Buffalo Bill: Letters to George T. Beck, 1895-1910 (Acc. #9972)

div1.note: Buffalo Bill's Wild West Combined With Pawnee Bill's Great Far East.
div1.p: Thanks for your letter. I will see Mr Murphy2 week after next. he lives in Philadelphia. I am in touch with lots of finalcialfinancial men now. But did not mention Oil to them, only Gold. Silver & Copper But It may be an oil deal would strike them favorably. What about the Painter Copper3 property? I wish you would find out for sure if I am the 9th man4. Tom Foley5 is so forgetful.
Write me fully what to say to Mr Murphy.

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West Combined with Pawnee Bill's Great Far East performed in New York, N.Y., from April 27 through May 15, 1909.
Note 2: Mr. Murphy is not identified.

Note 3: The Painter Copper property was likely that owned by John Robinson Painter (b.1861), a Philadelphia importer of Swiss musical instruments. In 1896 on a hunt in the Big Horn Basin, Painter fell in love with Sunlight Basin (north of Cody and south of the Beartooth Mountains). Painter sold his business, transported himself and his family from Philadelphia, and became a mining man, establishing the Sunlight Copper Mining Company, which contained copper, silver, and gold ores.
Note 4: Cody's reference to "the 9th man" is unclear.

Note 5: Colonel Tom Foley, a friend of William F. Cody's who accompanied Cody on a hunt in 1907 in the mountains above TE Ranch; from a photograph taken on this hunt and entitled "Camp Foley," Cody commissioned a commemorative oil painting by the artist Robert Farrington Elwell.
